articleinfo.title: Fedict eID Trust Service Administrator Manual
articleinfo.subtitle: Version &project.version;

abstract.para: This manual serves as an entry point for setting up the eID Trust Service. The target audience is system administrators.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document (in uppercase, as shown) are to be interpreted as described in [RFC2119] .

The eID Trust Service provides two major services:
eID Trust Service portal
Via this web portal citizens can check the validity of their eID certificates.
eID Trust Service validation web service
Via this SOAP web service Relying Parties (aka Service Providers) can check the validity of certificate chains. This web service has been implemented according to the W3C XKMS2 web service standard.
Besides these two service artifacts, the eID Trust Service also comes with an Admin portal. This portal allows administrators to manage the eID Trust Service via an easy to use interface. In the following sections we will use $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS as the (internal) web address where the eID Trust Service has been deployed.

The source code of the Fedict eID Trust Service is publicly available and can be found at eID Trust Service Source Code . The Fedict eID Trust Service has dependencies on jTrust, a Java library for trust validation of X509 certificates. This library can be found at jTrust source code . The Fedict eID Trust Service also has a dependency on the eID Applet project. This project can be found at eID Applet Project page .

section.title: Apache configuration under Redhat (Fedora)
section.para: The eID Trust Service runs on a JBoss 6.1 application server.

warning.title: Application Server Security
warning.para: Proper firewalling/front-end protection should be put in place to prevent unauthorized access towards the application server. In a production environment special care should be given not to expose the entire context path, i.e. / , towards the internet. This would allow anyone to deploy Java EE application via the JBoss JMX Console. A commonly used front-end is the Apache HTTPD web service.

section.para: We assume that you have installed a vanilla RedHat/CentOS operating system. Activate the Apache HTTP Service via: sudo chkconfig --level 345 httpd on chkconfig --list httpd sudo /etc/init.d/httpd restart In case you terminate the unilateral SSL on Apache, you need to install the SSL module via: sudo yum install mod_ssl.i686

section.title: iptables configuration under RedHat
section.para: Open up the iptables firewall on the Apache server to allow for both HTTP (port 80) and HTTPS (port 443). Relevant iptables configuration lines (under /etc/sysconfig/iptables ) are: -A INPUT -p tcp -m state --state NEW -m tcp --dport 80 -j ACCEPT -A INPUT -p tcp -m state --state NEW -m tcp --dport 443 -j ACCEPT Check the firewall setting on Redhat (Fedora) via: sudo cat /etc/sysconfig/iptables On RedHat/CentOS you can also configure the firewall via: system-config-firewall-tui Disable the NetworkManager via (Fedora only): sudo /etc/init.d/NetworkManager stop sudo chkconfig --level 2345 NetworkManager off chkconfig --list NetworkManager sudo reboot Enable the (static) network management via: sudo chkconfig --level 345 network on chkconfig --list network and check whether the levels 3, 4, and 5 are on.
The default network configuration can be found under: /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0

section.title: eID Trust Service Portal
section.para: After deployment of the eID Trust Service product, the eID Trust Service Portal is available at $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-portal/ . This web portal MUST be accessed over unilateral SSL. If not, the eID Applet will refuse to operate. The SSL SHOULD be terminated on the front-end Apache HTTPD service so that the SSL information can be communicated to the JBoss Application Service over the AJP protocol. If such a setup is not possible this SHOULD be clearly communicated in advance to the eID Trust Service development team so they can properly configure the eID Applet Service that is used within the eID Trust Service Portal.

Add the following configuration to your Apache HTTPD service to accomplish this: <IfModule mod_proxy_ajp.c> ProxyVia On
<Location /eid-trust-service-portal> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass ajp://localhost:8009/eid-trust-service-portal </Location>
<Location /eid-trust-service-admin-portal> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass ajp://localhost:8009/eid-trust-service-admin-portal </Location>
<Location /eid-trust-service-ws> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass ajp://localhost:8009/eid-trust-service-ws </Location>
<Location /eid-trust-service-ocsp> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass ajp://localhost:8009/eid-trust-service-ocsp </Location> </IfModule> For Redhat (Fedora) you add this file under /etc/httpd/conf.d/trust-service.conf .
Restart Apache via: sudo /etc/init.dhttpd restart or via: sudo service httpd restart

If you don't want to use the AJP protocol between the Apache web server and the JBoss application server, you can use the following configuration. <IfModule mod_proxy_ajp.c> ProxyRequests Off
<Location /eid-trust-service-portal> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass http://localhost:8080/eid-trust-service-portal ProxyPass http://localhost:8080/eid-trust-service-portal </Location>
<Location /eid-trust-service-admin-portal> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass http://localhost:8080/eid-trust-service-admin-portal ProxyPassReverse http://localhost:8080/eid-trust-service-admin-portal </Location>
<Location /eid-trust-service-ws> Order allow,deny Allow from all ProxyPass http://localhost:8080/eid-trust-service-ws </Location> </IfModule>

section.title: eID Trust Service Validation Web Service
section.para: After deployment of the eID Trust Service product, the eID Trust Service validation web service is available at $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-ws/xkms2 . This SOAP web service MUST be accessible via both HTTP and HTTPS (unilateral SSL). When this web service is accessed over plain HTTP, the service provides the possibility to sign the response messages using WS-Security. This can be configured via the Administrator portal.

section.title: eID Trust Service Admin Portal
section.para:
After deployment of the eID Trust Service, the eID Trust Service Admin Portal is available via: $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-admin-portal/
. This web portal MUST be accessed over unilateral SSL. If not, the eID Applet will refuse to operate.

warning.title: Administrator Registrations
warning.para: After a first start up of the eID Trust Service you need to register yourself an administrator by logging in into the eID Trust Service admin portal. Multiple administrators are possible.

section.title: SNMP
section.para: The eID Trust Service yields different SNMP counters on port 7894 (UDP).

section.title: Database
section.para: The eID Trust Service product requires a relational database to operate. The application server requires the proper JDBC driver to access the DBMS.

section.title: Java Virtual Machine
section.para: You need to have Java Sun 1.6.0_33 or higher installed. JDK or JRE are sufficient. These can be found at: Java download . After installation you will have to make sure that the environment variable $JAVA_HOME is properly set and the java program is available in the $PATH . Under Redhat (Fedora) you can create a /etc/profile.d/java.sh file containing the following: export JAVA_HOME=/usr/local/jdk1.6 export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH Where we assume that you installed the JDK under /usr/local/jdk1.6 . Check whether Sun Java 1.6.0_33+ is installed via the following command: java -version

The eID Trust Service also has been tested on a Java 7 runtime. If you want to run the eID services on a Java 7 runtime, we recommend Java 7u9+. In the past, previous versions of the JVM resulted in various errors.

section.title: JBoss Application Server
section.para:
The JBoss Application Server offers:
AJP at port: 8009
HTTP at port: 8080
HTTPS at port: 8443
AJP is preferred for the connection between the front-end Apache HTTPD and the JBoss Application Server.
The JBoss application server comes with an SSL configuration using a self-signed certificate. This SSL configuration is for testing purposes only and SHOULD NOT be used in production environments.

section.title: Installation
section.para: This chapter explains how to install the Fedict eID Trust Service application.

The Fedict eID Trust Service application server is based on the JBoss Application Server version 6.1.0.Final. The eID Trust Service comes in pre-packaged distributions containing a functional application server targetting a specific database product.

The Fedict eID Trust Service application is delivered in a customized database specific zip file. When unpacking this zip file, you will notice 2 directories: jboss and sql . The jboss directory contains the JBoss application server, configured for your DBMS product and pre-packaged with the Fedict eID Trust Service application. The sql directory contains the database initialization scripts. MySQL, PostgreSQL and Oracle are supported.

It is also possible to run the Fedict eID Trust Service application using HSQLDB, which is the default configured database for the JBoss Application Server. You will have to use the JBoss distribution from the Fedict eID Application Server project. This customized distribution has all necessary dependencies included to run the Fedict eID Trust Service. Please note that it is not recommended to use this setup in a production environment. The HSQLDB database product is not suited for production deployments. This setup should only be used for development and testing purposes.

section.title: Database setup
section.para: Before starting the JBoss Application Server you have to initialize your database. The initialization scripts can be found in the sql directory. There are 3 scripts: one to create the database account, one to create the Fedict eID Trust Service database, and one to initialize its tables. The default username/password for the trust database is trust/trust . Please note that if you change this, you have to manually modify the datasource configuration in the JBoss AS distribution. This configuration can be found in jboss/server/all/deploy/trust-service-ds.xml or jboss/server/default/deploy/trust-service-ds.xml , depending on the JBoss configuration that you prefer.

The Fedict eID Trust Service has been successfully tested on:
MySQL v5.0 and v5.1
Oracle 10.2.0.1.0
PostgreSQL 8.4.5

section.title: MySQL database setup on Redhat (Fedora)
section.para: The following is needed for setting up the MySQL database on Redhat (Fedora): sudo yum install mysql-server.i686 sudo /etc/init.d/mysqld start sudo mysql_secure_installation mysql -u root -p < mysql-create-account.sql mysql -u trust -p < mysql-create-database.sql mysql -u trust -p trust < mysql-trust-service-ddl.sql Check the availability of the MySQL DBMS via: mysql -u trust -p trust SHOW tables; QUIT; Check whether the MySQL service is started at boot time via: chkconfig --list mysqld Enable the MySQL service via: sudo chkconfig --level 345 mysqld on Drop an existing MySQL database via: mysql -u trust -p DROP DATABASE trust; QUIT;

section.title: Oracle database setup on Debian
section.para: Download the Oracle 10g Release 2 package @ Oracle 10g Release 2 . For further installation please check out Oracle installation on Debian . The sql directory contains initialization scripts for setting up an Oracle tablespace in the default XE database. Simply execute: sqlplus @oracle-init-trust-service.sql This might require setting some environment variables: export ORACLE_HOME=/usr/lib/oracle/xe/app/oracle/product/10.2.0/server export PATH=$ORACLE_HOME/bin:$PATH Check the database via: sqlplus trust/trust; SQL> select table_name from user_tables; SQL> exit

warning.title: Oracle permissions
warning.para: As the JBoss Oracle distribution is configured for an XA datasource some extra permissions are required to be granted to the trust database user. The oracle-create-account.sql script does this for you but is preconfigured for Oracle 10g Release 2 without patch for bug 5945463. For later versions the grant on sys.dbms_system needs to be changed to sys.dbms_xa.

section.title: PostgreSQL database setup on Redhat (Fedora)
section.para: The following is needed for setting up the PostgreSQL database on Redhat (Fedora): sudo yum install postgresql-server.i686 sudo service postgresql initdb sudo /etc/init.d/postgresql start
Check whether the PostgreSQL service is started at boot time via: chkconfig --list postgresql
Enable the PostgreSQL service via: sudo chkconfig --level 345 postgresql on

As JPA requires prepared transactions, we need to enable this feature on the PostgreSQL database. Change the PostgreSQL configuration file /var/lib/pgsql/data/postgresql.conf : max_prepared_transactions = 10

Change the PostgreSQL client authentication by editing the following lines in /var/lib/pgsql/data/pg_hba.conf : local all all md5 host all all 127.0.0.1/32 md5 Of course this assumes that the JBoss application server and the PostgreSQL DBMS are running on the same machine.
Create a PostgreSQL user and database via: psql -U postgres < postgresql-create-account-database.sql
Create the eID Trust Service tables in the PostgreSQL trust database via: psql -d trust -U trust -W -f postgresql-trust-service-ddl.sql
Check the database via: psql -d trust -U trust SELECT table_name FROM information_schema.tables WHERE table_schema = 'public'; \q
Drop an existing database via: psql -U postgres DROP DATABASE trust; \q

section.title: Resources
section.para: As the harvesting of large CRLs can be memory intensive, the JBoss Application Server has been tweaked so the JVM has more available memory. By default it is set to reserve a total of 1GB of heap space. The configuration can be found in jboss/bin/run.conf See Useful links for more info on tweaking this. The machine hosting the JBoss application server should have at least 2 GiB of available memory.
As to the amount of network traffic, this is highly related as to how CRL caching is configured.

The default connection pool size is 20. The maximum size of the database depends on the used DBMS and is approximately 4 GiB. Since the database mainly contains data which is available in the public CRLs, no extra backup strategy is required.
The application is using local storage for storing the temporary CRL downloads. Furthermore the JMS implementation of JBoss (HornetQ) is also using local storage for its journals.

The application requires a private key (JKS, PKCS#12 or PKCS#11 are possible) to be able to sign outgoing XKMS responses (WS-Security based message signing). The eID Trust Service also offers a proxy OCSP Responder. This proxy OCSP Responder is also using the service identity to sign the OCSP responses.

One can use the jvisualvm tool that comes with the Sun JDK to inspect the local running JBoss application server. Connect to a remote server via: ssh -X 192.168.1.101 jvisualvm & Different plugins can be configured as part of jvisualvm to enhance its monitoring capabilities.

section.title: Clustering
section.para: Following is needed for a basic clustering with load balancing setup. Since JBoss 6 M1, clustering has been simplified via mod_cluster . Unlike mod_jk and mod_proxy , mod_cluster leverages an additional connection between the application server nodes and httpd. The application server nodes use this connection to transmit server-side load balance factors and lifecycle events back to httpd via a custom set of HTTP methods, affectionately called the Mod-Cluster Management Protocol (MCMP). This additional feedback channel allows mod_cluster to offer a level of intelligence and granularity not found in other load balancing solutions.

section.title: JBoss Configuration
section.para: By default sticky sessions will be enabled. Yet at the time of writing their is an issue in mod_cluster if you do not explicitely specify a jvmRoute . See MODCLUSTER-146 for more info. Do this as follows: > vim jboss/server/all/deploy/jbossweb.sar/server.xml // add jvmRoute="node01" in <Engine name="jboss.web" ... >

section.title: Httpd Configuration
section.para:
First you will have to download the mod_cluster 's needed Apache modules @ mod_cluster . After having completed the installation, here is a basic httpd.conf setup: LoadModule proxy_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_proxy.so LoadModule proxy_ajp_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_proxy_ajp.so LoadModule slotmem_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_slotmem.so LoadModule manager_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_manager.so LoadModule proxy_cluster_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_proxy_cluster.so LoadModule advertise_module /opt/jboss/httpd/lib/httpd/modules/mod_advertise.so
LogLevel debug
CreateBalancers 1
<VirtualHost *:80>
<Location /mod_cluster-manager> SetHandler mod_cluster-manager
Order deny,allow Deny from all Allow from all # Allow from 192.168.7. </Location>
<Directory /> Order deny,allow Deny from all Allow from all </Directory>
ProxyPass /eid-trust-service-admin-portal balancer://mycluster/eid-trust-service-admin-portal
KeepAliveTimeout 60 MaxKeepAliveRequests 0 ManagerBalancerName mycluster AdvertiseFrequency 5
</VirtualHost> Beware in this setup the mod_cluster-manager is set open for testing purposes. This way you can view the connected nodes @ ./mod_cluster-manager . More information on more advanced setups can be found in the Useful links section.

section.title: Starting
section.para: The eID Trust Service JBoss distribution comes with two JBoss configurations. The default configuration and the all configuration. Use the all configuration if you are interested in running the eID Trust Service as part of a cluster.

After you have correctly setup your database, you can start the application server by executing the following command: ./jboss/bin/run.sh -b 0.0.0.0 & . Or in case you want to run the JBoss configuration that enables clustering, you start via: ./jboss/bin/run.sh -b 0.0.0.0 -c all & The option -b 0.0.0.0 changes the bind address of the server so it becomes available on all interfaces. This option is not necessary when using an AJP front-end web server.

Background processes can easily be managed using screen . First you start screen via: screen Then start the JBoss application server via ./jboss/bin/run.sh Detach the screen via Ctrl-a d . List the available screen processes via screen -ls Re-attach to a background screen process via screen -r <screen process name>

warning.title: eID Trust Service Administrator registration
warning.para: The first time you start the eID Trust Service you should register a trust service administrator via the admin portal.

section.para:
After the application has started, it will have initialized itself with 4 trust domains.
eID Authentication Trust Domain ( machine domain name BE-AUTH )
eID Non Repudiation Trust Domain ( machine domain name BE )
eID National Registry Trust Domain ( machine domain name BE-NAT-REG )
Belgian TSA Trust Domain ( machine domain name BE-TSA )
The default trust domain will be set to the eID Authentication Trust Domain.

In order to function properly, the application needs to be able to make outgoing calls for CRL, OCSP. If you are running behind a proxy, you can setup the proxy using the administration portal. Optionally the application also needs to be able to make outgoing calls for TSP or NTP.
CRL download URLs for the Belgian eID Trust Domains are typically something like http://crl.eid.belgium.be/eidc200501.crl . The URL is retrieved from the validated certificate chain.
OCSP requests for the Belgian eID Trust Domains are typically sent to http://ocsp.eid.belgium.be . The URL is again retrieved from the validated certificate chain.
TSP requests can be used for clock drift detection. The location is configurable in the Administrator portal.
The NTP protocol can also be used for clock drift detection. The location is configurable in the Administrator portal.

section.title: Stopping
section.para: Graceful shutdown can be accomplished via: ./jboss/bin/shutdown.sh -S After this you can check if shutdown completed properly via: ps -ef | grep java

section.title: Init script for Redhat (Fedora)
section.para: Copy the orginal supplied init script: cp $JBOSS_HOME/bin/jboss_init_redhat.sh /etc/init.d/jboss Change the permissions on the new jboss init script: sudo chmod 755 /etc/init.d/jboss You might need to changed the following in the JBoss script: #!/bin/sh # chkconfig: 345 90 10 # description: JBoss AS eID Services # processname: jboss ... JBOSS_HOME="location of your JBoss distribution" JBOSS_USER="the user that will be used to run the JBoss application server under" JAVAPTH="the location of your JVM" JBOSS_CONF="default" ... To bind to the correct IP address, modify the line: JBOSS_BIND_ADDR=${JBOSS_HOST:+"-b $JBOSS_HOST"} to JBOSS_BIND_ADDR=${JBOSS_BIND_ADDR:-"-b your.ip.address.here"} To get a log file, modify the line: JBOSS_CONSOLE=${JBOSS_CONSOLE:-"/dev/null"} to JBOSS_CONSOLE=${JBOSS_CONSOLE:-"/location/of/your/logs/jboss-console.log" Register the jboss service as followes chkconfig --add jboss chkconfig --list jboss Start and stop the jboss service via service jboss start service jboss stop
You can change the temporary directory used by the JVM to store the CRL files and such via: JBOSSSH ... -Djava.io.tmpdir=...

section.title: Transaction timeouts
section.para: The downloading and processing of large CRLs can take a lot of time. This can lead to MDB transaction timeouts. By default, the custom JBoss MySQL and Oracle Distributions have a transaction timeout configured of 1200 seconds or 20 minutes. This should be sufficient. If this still proves to be insufficient, this can be changed in jboss/server/default/deploy/transaction-jboss-beans.xml . Look for the following line and change accordingly: <property name="defaultTimeout">1200</property> . After changing this the JBoss Application Server has to be restarted as followed: ./jboss/bin/shutdown.sh -S ./jboss/bin/run.sh -b 0.0.0.0 Please check if the shutdown was completed before restarting.

section.title: Configuring Redhat (Fedora) as an eID Trust Service
section.para: The network interface should not be managed by the NetworkManager but should start at boot time. Check that /etc/sysconfig/network_scripts/ifcfg_eth0 contains the following lines: ONBOOT=yes NM_CONTROLLED=no USERCTL=no Disable the graphical user interface at startup by setting the runlevel in /etc/inittab to 3: id:3:initdefault:

section.title: Configuration of the NTP-client on Redhat (Fedora)
section.para: The eID Trust Service functionality is very dependent on a correct local time.

Configure your NTP servers via /etc/ntp.conf . Configure the NTP client service via: sudo chkconfig --level 345 ntpd on chkconfig --list ntpd Start the NTP service via: sudo /etc/init.d/ntpd start . Check whether the local clock is correctly synchronized via: ntpdate -q your.ntp.server.com

section.title: JBoss Logging
section.para:
The JBoss Application Server's logging configuration can be found in jboss/server/default/deploy/jboss-logging.xml . All logging from the Fedict eID Trust Service components is configured to output to a seperate log file which can be found in jboss/server/default/log/fedict.log . By default the logging granularity is set to DEBUG . You can change this by changing the level of the configured Fedict logger: <logger category="be.fedict"> <level name="DEBUG" /> <handlers> <handler-ref name="FEDICT" /> </handlers> </logger> In the same way you can change JBoss' logging too.
Production configuration
For production configurations you should change the logging from DEBUG to ERROR .

section.title: Database
section.para: To view the contents of the database behind the Fedict eID Trust Service, one can use the SQuirrel SQL Client . This SQL client allows you to view the structure of any database that comes with a JDBC driver.

To be able to connect to your HSQL/MySQL/Oracle database you will need to configure a JDBC driver. You can download the drivers @ MySQL JDBC Driver and
Oracle JDB Driver
. Configure your driver in SQuirrel SQL by selecting the appropriate one, select Modify Driver... and add your JDBC driver JAR in the Extra Class Path tab.

When you are done with this, you can configure the connection to the database by adding a new Alias . Select the appropriate driver, and configure the URL, username and password as is configured in the Fedict eID Trust Service datasource file ( jboss/server/default/deploy/trust-service-ds.xml ).

section.title: Administration Portal
section.para: The Fedict eID Trust Service comes with an administration portal. This portal allows you to setup your network proxy if any, manage trust domains and other aspects of the service.

section.title: Administrator registration
section.para: To login into the administrator portal, an eID authentication will be performed. If the service was freshly installed, the first successfully authenticated user will be automatically registered as administrator. Subsequent administrators will have to be accepted by this one. Performing a login will add you as a pending administrator which can subsequently be approved by another existing administrator.

section.title: Administrators
section.para: Here you can view existing and pending administrators, approve pending administrators, remove administrators.

section.title: WS-Security Configuration
section.para: The eID Trust Service Validation Web Service has the possibility to optionally sign its response message using WS-Security. The keystore to be used for this can be configured via the admin portal. There is support for JKS, PKCS#11 and PKCS#12 keystores. The keystore path in case of PKCS#11 is the path to the configuration file which will be used by the Sun PKCS#11 provider.
The proxy OCSP Responder is also using this service identity for signing the OCSP responses.

section.title: Network Configuration
section.para: If you are operating behind a proxy, you can setup this in here and enable or disable the proxy configuration. The proxy configuration is used for CRL downloads and for OCSP requests.

section.title: Clock Drift Detection
section.para: The Fedict eID Trust Service comes with built in support for NTP and TSP. TSP or Timestamp Protocol is a protocol used for certifying timestamps. A timestamp request will be sent to the configured TSA server, returning a timestamp response containing a timestamp token. The received timestamp token will be used for clock drift detection.
You can configure the times when to perform the clock drift detection check using a cron-like expression string. See Cron schedules for more info.

section.title: Information Message
section.para: The information message to be shown on $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-portal can be configured here for all available languages of the Fedict eID Trust Service Portal.

section.title: Virtual Trust Domains
section.para: Virtual trust domains are a group of existing trust domains. Users of the eID Trust Service Validation Web Service have the possibility to specify a virtual trust domain to validate against.

section.title: Trust Domains
section.para: You can add, modify, remove trust domains here. Also you can set the default trust domain for the Fedict eID Trust Service. This trust domain will be used in the eID Trust Service Validation Web Service if no trust domain was specified. For each trust domain you can specify whether or not CRL caching should be used, which trust points lie under this trust domain and which certificate contraints are too be enforced when validating against this trust domain. See Cron schedules for more info.

section.title: Trust Points
section.para: For each trust point, you can specify a cron expression for specifying the CRL cache cron schedule interval. This includes refreshing all underlying CA's that have been cached. You can also refresh the CRL cache immediately here for debugging purposes. For each trust point you can see the list of CA's associated with this trust point and for each CA you can refresh the cache individually.

section.title: CRL Cache
section.para: The CRL Cache page gives you an overview of the state of the CRL cache on a per CA basis. Per CA you can manually trigger a refresh of its CRL cache, or remove its CRL cache altogether.
Because the proxy OCSP Responder requires all used intermediate CA's to be known within the eID Trust Service, you can also cold start the CRL Cache from this page.

section.title: Audit logging
section.para:
Following events will be logged by the FedICT eID Trust Service and can be consulted in the admin portal.
Error contacting NTP server
Maximum clock offset reached
Failed to download CRL for CA=...
Invalid CRL for CA=...
Failed to parse CRL for CA=...
Failed to notify harvester for CA=...
Default trust domain not set
CA not found for ...

section.title: SNMP
section.para:
The Fedict eID Trust Service has several SNMP counters available to monitor the health of the application. These counters can be retrieved by invoking the command: snmpget -v 2c -c public localhost:7894 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.0.0 . The available SNMP counters are:
# of validations ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.0.0 )
# of CRL cache refreshes ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.1.0 )
# of CRL cache hits ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.2.0 )
# of CRL cache misses ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.3.0 )
CRL cache hit % ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.4.0 )
# of CRL download failures ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.5.0 )
# of OCSP request failures ( OID = 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890.6.0 )
Install the SNMP tools on RedHat (Fedora) via: sudo yum install net-snmp-utils.i686 Check all available SNMP counters via: snmpwalk -v 2c -c public localhost:7894 1.3.6.1.4.1.7890

section.title: CRON expression
section.para:
You can specify a cron-like expression for the clock drift detection task and for each trust point's cache refreshment. So for example: 0 0 0/3 * * * is valid and represents, every 3 hours. The cron schedule string consist of following fields.
All cron fields and default values.
Attribute Allowable Values Default
Second [0,59] 0
Minute [0,59] 0
Hour [0,23] 0
dayOfMonth [1,31] *
Month [1,12] *
dayOfWeek [0,7] *
Year A four-digit calendar year *
For a more complete view of what is allowed, check the EJB 3.1 specification's TimerService/ScheduleExpression section.

section.title: Sanity checks
section.para: To check whether an installed eID Trust Service instance operates normally you can try to validate your eID certificates via the eID Trust Service portal. This portal is available at: $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-portal/ . The following page can be used to check whether the eID Trust Service instance is still alive: $EID_TRUST_SERVICE_ADDRESS/eid-trust-service-portal/main.seam

section.title: Test eID Cards
section.para: For the eID Trust Service to be able to accept test eID cards, you need to configure a trust domain for this. Per default the eID Trust Service comes pre-configured with a BE-TEST trust domain that accepts test eID cards. Most important aspect when configuring a trust domain for test eID cards is that you configure the right certificate policy OID as 2.16.56.1.40.40.40.1 and that you of course add the eID test Root CA as trust point.

section.title: Monitoring
section.para: Measuring the application performance can be a very important asset for troubleshooting and maintenance. collectd is a very good utility for measuring all kinds of metrics on your server, from system level metrics utilisation to application level JMX parameters. While collectd is great for measuring, transporting and storage of metrics, it offers little support for alerting and notifications.

You probably will have to compile collectd yourself to have the Java plugin enabled. First install some required dependencies: yum install rrdtool-devel.x86_64 yum install libcurl-devel.x86_64 yum install OpenIPMI-devel.x86_64 Configure, build and install collectd via: ./configure --enable-java --with-java=/usr/local/jdk1.6.0_33 make sudo make install Next listing gives an example configuration of /opt/collectd/etc/collectd.conf . Interval 60
LoadPlugin disk <Plugin disk> Disk "sda" </Plugin>
LoadPlugin "logfile" <Plugin "logfile"> LogLevel "info" File "/opt/collectd/var/log/collectd.log" Timestamp true </Plugin>
LoadPlugin "rrdtool" <Plugin "rrdtool"> DataDir "/opt/collectd/var/lib/collectd/rrd" CacheFlush 120 WritesPerSecond 50 </Plugin>
LoadPlugin "cpu" LoadPlugin "df" LoadPlugin "memory" LoadPlugin "swap"
LoadPlugin "java" <Plugin "java"> JVMARG "-Djava.class.path=/opt/collectd/share/collectd/java/collectd-api.jar:/opt/collectd/share/collectd/java/generic-jmx.jar" LoadPlugin "org.collectd.java.GenericJMX" <Plugin "GenericJMX"> <MBean "memory_pool"> ObjectName "java.lang:type=MemoryPool,*" Instanceprefix "memory_pool-" InstanceFrom "name" <Value> Type "memory" Table true Attribute "Usage" </Value> </MBean> <MBean "classes"> ObjectName "java.lang:type=ClassLoading" InstancePrefix "classes" <Value> Type "gauge" InstancePrefix "loaded_classes" Table false Attribute "LoadedClassCount" </Value> </MBean> <MBean "ajp"> ObjectName "jboss.web:type=GlobalRequestProcessor,name=ajp-127.0.0.1-8009" InstancePrefix "ajp" <Value> Type "derive" InstancePrefix "request_count" Table false Attribute "requestCount" </Value> </MBean> <Connection> Host "localhost" ServiceURL "service:jmx:rmi:///jndi/rmi://localhost:1090/jmxrmi" Collect "memory_pool" Collect "classes" Collect "ajp" </Connection> </Plugin> </Plugin> Here we let collectd to generate RRD files. We also use the JMX plugin to monitor the JBoss application server directly. Use the RRDTool for further processing of the RRD metric files.
